text:
375 mL bottle.

Clear golden body. Medium white head and collar.

Smells acidic and musty. Some pumpkin comes through.

Taste has sharp sourness up front. Woody here. I still get some pumpkin, but it isnt as strong as it is in the aroma. I get a lot more molasses, though.

Medium high carbonation. Medium body.

Eh. Dont love the combination of flavors so much.

Small white head over clear orangeish golden beer. Bretts, saddlesoap and fine sherry, as much as dried peach. Remarkably complex nose. Old wine, sherry, fine malts, bit sweet. Medium bodied, seems thinned by... Great! A pumpkin beer I really like is rare, to put it mildly.

Orange tan in color, slightly hazy... Aroma of pumpkin, sour notes, hay, funk... Flavor is pumpkin, hay, citrus, funk, caramel malts, pumpkin seed... Funk and citrus on palate... Great beer 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12.7oz bottle in a tulip on my 30th. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma of sourness/tartness, some light funk, hints of pumpkin or something, some oak and wine, and light malts. Flavor the same with a good blend. Average texture. A cool beer.

Bottle as "Ghoulschip." An interesting hybrid of the flavors of Allagashs brett beers and their coolship beers, with a lot of distinct pumpkin notes as well. The yeasts give it some of the character of their spontaneous ales, though not all of the complexity. Theres a noticeable creaminess and toasted seed flavor from the pumpkins, which is really distinct, but this is not a spiced beer at all.

375ml bottle thanks to Toby. Pours out a hazy peach color topped with a small white head. Nose is lots of oak barrel plenty sour funk some fruit. Taste is more of the sour tartness funky lots of barrel.
Bottle as Ghoulschip - pours gold white head - nose and taste of molasses, pumpkin, sour earthy funk and toasted seed - medium body
Pours hazy golden color very murky with a white film. Aroma has funk tart spice hints of pumpkin. Taste is tart mild spiced with faint pumpkin thanksgiving spices. Palate is medium and dry.
Free! Taster at the source. Pours orange coppet withan off white head. Aroma is oak, white wine, yam. Flavor is lemon tart up front, with pumpkin, dry white wine, oak.

Sampled at the brewery. Orange in color liquid with a thicker, huge carbonation level. Aroma is white wine, oak barrel and a earthy spice. Flavor is huge in the white wine barrel. Lingering oak in the finish. Its almost all wine barrel. Not really my thing.
Yeast and fruity aroma. Draft pour at Allagash taproom. Orange and clear with white head. Sour and smooth. Good. Not getting the pumpkin

Draft pour at the Great Pumpkin beer fest. Listed as Allagash Ghoulschip. This beer made the whole festival worth it. Awesome! Pours a cloudy orange color with a fizz head. Big pucker sour fruit aroma and flavor. Just enough pumpkin to know its there. So awesome.

I hate pumpkin beers but this is awesome. Great mix of real pumpkin and some bretta. Citrusy. Pours golden orange with good head and lacing. Tangy finish. Some crackery bretta. Nice. Tap at Snallygaster.
Draft pour at Snallygaster listed as Ghoulschip. Orange with off-white head. Aromas of light pumpkin and vinegar, oak. Tastes of vinegar, light pumpkin, tart notes. Light body with a dry finish.
Ok brew, some spice in tart nose. Flavor of tart and breads sour dogh breads. Some oak funk and some barnyard.

Bottle at franks. Pours a hazy orange with thin white lacing. Aroma is horrid - putrid funk and off flavors. Mouthfeel is lightly tart and fruity. Maybe some earthy funk as well. Seems past its prime.

375ml bottle of Ghoulschip b2 Fall 2014 release, pours hazy toasted orange with a finger of head. Nose is musty wet oak and basement wood beams, touches of soft earthy bread crust spice, funky barrel, honey. Taste is tart oak-heavy, some subtle earthy pumpkin and squash, though not in an overly spiced way, wet gourd, some soft sweet roasted nut and honey and toasted bread. Finish is tart musty wood funk, squash, wet oak, light Fall fruit spice.
375 ml bottle to stemmed taster. Looks solid; a cloudy dark apricot with virtually no lacing. Smells and tastes mildly tart and spicy with a nicely balanced pumpkin presence. Enjoyable.

Been trying to tick this one for years and finally got a bottle... Poured golden/yellow with a thin, whispy head. Aroma of funk, cheese, squash, pumpkin seeds, and citrus zest. Moderate mouthfeel with decent funk, black pepper spice, citrus rind and zest, musky, and very vegetal in squash flavor. Moderate acidity and not totally sour. Super drinkable.
(Backlog) Draft at allagash event at barcade jersey city, as ghoulschip. Orange pour devoid of head. Tart, pumpkin, brett and spice aromas. Oak, vanilla, pumpkin, tart tones and a touch of spice.

375mL bottle, pours a cloudy orange with a small white head. Aroma brings out tart fruits, pumpkins, and light funk. Flavour brings out lovely tart notes, some moderate pumpkin notes, and some light funk. Very complex, with a lingering tart finish. Very nice stuff.
Amber pour, off white head. Flavors if squash, Balsamic, oak, sour, funky and quite good!

Draught at Armsby Abbey, Summer 2012, as GhoulschipQuite carbonated is the glowing orange body (deep, burnished copper-amber) and it sports a small, off-white head that sticks around a covering, leaving bits of lacing. Clarity is good.Musty basement notes, vegetables (rhubarb, celery) and touches of caramel and vanilla are all pretty well melded together, if you can believe that? Its got a sweet edge to it, with some very light brett notes that dont really have the full force of tartness that most "brett beers" have. Strange, indeed, but quite intriguing.Lightly slick, somewhat sticky palate, has a creamy, tight carbonation that gives this beer a bit more body than it, perhaps, wants, but the light oak tannins, brett acids and nuttiness from the pumpkin seeds all serve to keep it mostly dry on the finish, with some light alcohol warmth that seems well-placed. Reminds me more of something like Saison de Pipaix, than it does something like Allagash Interlude (couldnt really think of a good adjunct, wine-barrel-aged brett Belgian to use as an example). Plenty of basement flavors coming from who knows where. Again, maybe not the most objectively delightful beer, but highly interesting and certainly drinkable. An aged bottle would more than likely be divine.

Bottle (375 ml). As Ghoulschip. Thanks to Daniel for this one! Beautiful bright and clear golden/orange with a small diminishing white head and little lacing. Aroma is of bourbon (subtle), brown sugar, vanilla, buttery notes, light sweetness, some fruits (pumpkin?), toasted notes and some spices (not overpowering though). Taste is gently tart with bourbon, vanilla, pumpkin, light spices, buttery notes and brown sugar. Medium body. Moderate carbonation. Slightly dry finish. Quite complex and amazing balance. Very nice pumpkin beer! In the same league as Elaborative #2. Drinkable.

bottle shared by tom10101, thanks bro. pours hazy bright golden-orange with a very nice white cap, good retention and nice lacing. very fruity toasted and buttery caramel malts, white wine oakiness, bretts and other wild bugs, spicy yeastiness - also some dust, some coconut, toffee, spiced rum, bitter herbs. moderate sweetness and acidity - complex acidic profile - lactic/citric/acetic, soft tannins. lively to average carbonation, light body - oily, drying bretty slightly astringent and herbal-grassy-spicy finish. very good - much enjoyed!

Bottle shared by tom10101, thanks for the rare opportunity! Pours a strong golden with a white ring that doesnt leave much lacing. Aroma is of bourbon, fruits and brown sugar. Taste is buttery and sweet caramel mixed with sour fruits. Not too much spices in this one and the bourbon isnt overpowering. Mouthfeel is juicy, carbonation level medium. Lovely!

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange amber with a small white head. Aroma was tart & earthy with brett, vinegar, oak and funk. Flavor was tart and sour with oak, wood, soft pumpkin, funk, earth and had mild acidity.

375 ml bottle (consumed Feb. 2012, from notes). Pours a slightly hazy orange amber color with a small white head. The aroma is nicely tart, acidic, Brett funk, some citrus, fleshy pumpkin/squash notes and oak. The flavor has some fleshy pumpkin/squash, oak, funk, citrus, some lactose sour character, but this kind of fades at the finish. Interesting, but ultimately falls a bit short.
Big pumpkin sour ale with a terrific flavor and finish.  This has flavor, added Bret and the wine barrel aging that makes this a tasty treat.

2011 Ghoulschip bottle.
Appearance: Hazy tea color, creamy head.
Aroma: Vinegar, fruity, and slightly sour.
Taste: Mildly tart, some vinegar, some oak, pumpkin, and light sweetness on finish.
Palate: Medium body, medium carbonation.
Overall: I like this, its tart/sour but lightly, very approachable.

Bottle tnx to Greg. Pours cloudy darker amber with a nice bbeige head leaving some lace. Aroma is funky sour some red berries malty fruity very fresh. Flavor is sour mellow some caramel acidy tart good maltyness finishing with nice tart sour and a bit pungent aftertaste.

Bottle shared at CPK, London - huge thanks to Bruce for sourcing this scarce one. Pours cloudy gold with a fine, white cream head. Moderate sourness and funk, some mellow gourd notes. Light bodied with fine carbonation. Lightly warming finish, decent sour edge, nice funky tang. Very drinkable. Awesome.

Bottle, cheers to deeblo for the pour! 6.9% edition. The pours a hazy amber orange color with a small head. The aromas sweet mashed pumpkin. Plenty of allspice, caramel, mild cat piss and funky attic. The taste is lacto, mineral, soft pumpkin fruitiness with accents of ginger and cinnamon. Sharp acidity in the finish. Big profile for a sour. Sort of ragged. Overall, pretty decent.

Bottle courtesy of CFrances... This thing is an enigma.  Huge mollases flavors dominate but a nice souring and toastyness are present as well.  A mishmash of flavors that shouldnt work but somehow do.  I liked it.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2013 Bottle as Ghoulschip 6.9%, thanks to deeblo. It pours cloudy orange with quickly dissipaiting white head. The nose is pumpkin, tart apricot, squash, earth, wood, light vanilla, coconut and faint sulphur. The taste is tart apricot, tangerine, white grape, sour pumpkin, saltiness, mild acidity, wood, earth, faint mustiness, subtle vanilla and touch of alcohol warmth with a dry, tart finish. Medium body and fine, carbonation. Pretty smooth, mellow, good depth of flavour and very drinkable.
Big thanks to Colin, great sweetness here, some funk, very little tart, some squash flavors, interesting

Bottle 375ml. corked. [ As Allagash Ghoulschip ].ABV: 6.9%. Clear medium amber orange colour with a small to average, frothy, good lacing, mostly diminishing to lasting, off-white to white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, tart, wood, light pumpkin. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light acidic with a long duration, tart, caramel, fruity, wood, brett, pumpkin notes. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [20121019]

Shared by Thorpe429 alongside several other Allagash sour/wild ales. Thank you very much, Mike!

The beer appears orange with a mild haze and a small, fizzy head. The aroma brings wild yeast, tart apples, oak. Nice flavor, though I couldnt pick out any pumpkin or squash character. Lactic finish with mild acidity. A bit of pucker. Fairly light in body and easy to drink. Another tasty wild ale from Allagash.
Bottle @ French Oktoberfest Tasting Ulfborg, 2012. Pours clear golden with a small white head. Spicy nose. Flavor is funk, almond, caramel and berries. A bit of vomit. Refreshing.

2008 Ghoulship Batch On Draft @ Novare Res Harvest Fest. Pours an orange golden color with a fizzy two finger head. On the nose its tart and funky. Basement brett barnyard notes mingle with sweet oaky vanilla and toasty sour pumpkin in the nose. On the palate it really comes together with bright funk blended with the sour earthy pumpkin and toasty seed notes. A nice background of wet wood, oak and light chardonnay and vanilla hints on the late palate... leading to a quenching finish. Overall a medium body sour that has many many layers of flavors. YUM !

Bottle @ fonefan tasting as Allagash Ghoulschip. Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, barnyard and wood. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate acidic. Dry and moderate acidic finish. 191012
Bottle @ FoneFan. Clear amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, fruit, pumpkin and sour. Flavour is malt, fruit, pumpkin, sour, tart, wood and oak.

rødgylden klar skum ingen 
jord græskar eddike malt 
sur moderat bitter lidt 
tør Medium blød
@f1 19-10-12
Draft: Armsby Abbey: Pours an amber/orange.  Aroma consists of vinegar, squash and pumpkin, with little to no spices . Notes of pumpkin are present and refreshingly are not masked by spices,

tap at ebenezers.    liked this quite a bit.   clean, soft moderate yogurt sourness, pumpkin comes across more like earthy strawberries.   some pleasant wet oak.   nice leathery dank cellar funk.   dry.  clean tasty beer.  nice enough

Draft.  Murky amber body, small white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, sour cherry, some wood, funk.  Taste is moderately sweet, sour cherry, wood, some funk, fairly tart.  Light-medium body, light acidity.  Im sure there was pumpkin in there, but didnt pick it up.

On tap as Ghoulschip thanks to LtDan and company. Pours with a hazy golden hued body with a scant white head that lasts as a ring. Aromas are much more sour than pumpkin beer. Brett character is strong, funky and earthy. Some phenols and a few spices beyond that. Some wine and low malt characters. A strong cheesy  aroma. Flavors are earthy, wine, vinous, woody, oak, a bit vegital, damp leaves, tart. Medium low carbonation, medium acid presence. Good.
Bottle sampled at Muckfest III. Clear gold/amber pour with a thin off-white head. Malty and fruity nose with some sourness. Fruity/winey flavor with some maltiness before an herbal and tart finish.

Bottle shared by ogglethorp at Muckfest III...thanks Brian! - Pours hazy amber with a filmy off-white head. Nose is lightly tart Smarties and pale malt. Mild, nondescript  fruitiness that I assume is the pumpkin. Taste has real mild breadiness, lots of yeast, a bit of cherry, and a touch of vinegar in the finish. Well-carbonated and fairly thick.

Bottle shared at MuckFest 3 - Saturday Edition. Pours a richer hazy glowing golden orange hue, a bit fiery with good orange glow, frothy offwhite head dies to a ring and laces small. Mellow ring. Aromas are funky brett, touches of lactic sourness, lemons, gentle spice, funk, brett. Touch of squash, bready malts. Oak, vanilla, and growing bretty funk, yeasty touch of Belgian life. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied, offering touches of pumpkin squash, touches of funk, straw, grass. Mellow pear, touch of crab apple, gentle tartness, funkiness grows. Fruity and pineapple into the middle. Touches of tropical fruit on the nose come through in the middle a bit more. Good flavors with richer fruity and citrusy flavors, touches of funk grow, mellow oak, sweeter doughy malts, honeycrisp apples. Finish is mellow tartness, melange of fruit, and a brett diven pineapple and funky feel. Solid offering here, underrated with some great play among the wild yeast. Very nice.

Draft at the Pour House in Westmont, NJ. 

Pours a hazy dark orange color with tangerine hues and a one finger frothy white head that quickly settles into a lasting ring. Splotchy lacing left behind.  Really nice color and good retention. 

Earthy, funky aroma with lots of oak, bretty bugs and lactic funk.  Very authentic smelling with quite a but horsey/barnyard character.  Slightly floral/vegetal but i would have never guessed that this beer was made with pumpkin or molasses.  Decent barrel presence with some vanilla and toasted oak.

Medium bodied with a tart, puckering mouthfeel and a decent amount of earthy funk.  Good sourness with subtle acetic vibegar but not harsh or solvent.  Nice barrel presence with dry oak and subtle vanilla flavor.  Decent amount of barnyard funk but it doesnt taste as authentic as it smells.  Some light fruit and citrus but Im not picking up any autumnal flavor.  No pumpkin, roast or molasses.  Well balanced and easy to dink with lingering tartness.

On tap at  EBF. By this point in the night I was somewhat tired of stouts and this sour was just the thing to re-energize my system. Great funk in the aroma mixed with a great sour tartness. Would love to drink this gem again.

Ghoulschip - On draft at the Barcade. Pours a hazy brownish orange.  Nose is tart Brett, light pumpkin spice, oak, and horse taint.  Taste is barnyard funk, oak, with a little pumpkin coming through.  Really solid

Bottle. Brownish pour without much head. Aroma actually smells a tad like pumpkin but mostly all brett, lots of oak as well, quite spicy smelling, interesting. Taste is sour, not puckeringly so, soft oak tannins, fruity without being sweet. Palate is rich, like most of the allagash sours they are a bit heavy. Fun beer.
From a ghoulschip bottle at Where the Wild Beers Are. Incredible aroma of pumpkin pie spices and funk. Flavor is the same--spicy and sour. Well done.

Bottle (Ghoulschip)... Murky amber ale with a mid-sized, creamy, white head. Good retention. The bouquet is funky and acutely acidic  aged cheese and sour cherries stand out. Medium-bodied with moderate carbonation. The flavor offers big-time cherries, tangy grapes and yeasty bitterness. Finishes tangy and bready. Bottle courtesy of landhoney!

Pours a murky orange/amber color with an off-white head.  Smells very metallic.  Not really any pumpkin, but I guess thats not that big of a surprise.  Some lactic tartness to it, maybe a little bit of oak and fruit (apple).  The flavor is also quite metallic, which just really ruins the beer.  Some tartness and oak, lightly tannic.  Not really much going on and not all that enjoyable.

On tap at Pour House. Pours a murkey pumpkin orange. Aromas of brett, barnyard, lactic acids, oaky pumpkin spices. Taste is a sour and oaky with vanilla and only a little bit of the pumpkin coming through. Reminded me of a temptation or a slightly less sour gueuze. Other notes of rye, and balck currants. Awesome and refreshing sour beer.

@ pourhouse as ghoulshcip.  Aroma is sweet with ginger, nutmeg, slight funk and meat.  Pours ugly hazy orange with slight lacing.  Taste is nice.  Spice forward with coreander, nutmeg and a slight funk.  Mild pucker but more sweet than tart.  Nice.

From notes.  First reviewed 12/14/2011.  Poured from a 375 mL bottle into a stemmed tulip.

The beer itself is a murky tangerine orange color with a brown center. Splotches of head exist instead of a real head. 

Lemon zest, barnyard funk, dry pumpkin, and some fall spices compose the aroma.

It is sweet and sour up front but not overly sour, with lemon zest combining with the dry malt up front. Pumpkin, clove, and allspice contribute to a dry, pumpkin tartness that combines a bit of malt and lemon zest at the end. 

It starts medium bodied with a soft creamy sweetness, then slowly becomes more acetic, dries out and finishes with a lighter body. A bit of residue sits on the inside of my lips. 

This is not my favorite sour. The other guys in my tasting group liked it better than me.

Nose is acidic - some oak, a bit of funk and some freshly carved pumpkin odors.  Pours a murky light tan color with white foam and a bit of lacing.  Taste is more sour than the nose indicates.  Its acidic and faintly vegetal.  At first it was pleasant, but the more I drank, the less I liked it.  Feel was nice - crisp, decently carbed and on the heavier side of light bodied.

sample at Brewvival on 2/25/12. orange pour with a white head. brett / oak / wine / light pumpkin on the nose. med body - perfect levels of funk and wine notes with a touch of pumpkin. semi-dry finish with more brett and light pumpkin.  one of my favorites at Brewvival this year!

Sampled at Brewvival 2012. Ghoulschip. Clear light amber pour with small whitish head.  Good funky earthy cheesy aroma.  Flavor was tart acidic cheese, and not very clean, but in a good way.  I really didnt particularly pick out the pumpkin notes, but there was a vegetalness to it.  I found it to be less complex than the mattina rossa.  Very solid sour though.

Served on draft at Brewvival under the Ghoulschip label. Pours a hazy amber color with a thin creamy tan head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, pumpkin, spice and a tart finish. The taste is pumpkin, earthy notes and an earthy, vegetal finish. Medium bodied.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured cloudy orange copper color with a large off-white frothy head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid doughy pumpkin, floral and wood aroma. Medium to full body with a creamy texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy balanced pumpkin floral bittersweet flavor with a medium  bittersweet finish of moderate to long duration. Good complex beer.
Draft at Maxs.  Hazy orange-brown pour with a thin white head.  Sour aroma with a bit of vinegar.  Sour metallic flavor.  Woody and vanilla bourbon notes.  Tart finish.

hazy orange amber, slight chill haze. Nose has huge fruit presence in acetic, lightly dry oak, high citrus. Flavor shows huge citrus and acetic notes at front, skin-like grape through mid, dry brett b finish, moderate acetic but little burn, very stale grains remain behind lightest dry spice. More acetic than spice but controlled.
Draft as Ghoulship.  Cloudy amber color.  Aroma of sour orange.  Taste is orange peel and white bread.  Nice.
Cherry brett and light acetic acid nose with lots of honey and sugar. Taste is fairly sweet, lots of honey and cherry, light acidity, some vinegar and a vegetal note that I assume is the pumpkin.

Tap at Maxs.  Pours lightly hazy amber with a medium, fizzy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is acetic vinegar and cherry with light caramel malt and fruity esters.  Flavor is sour fruits with light malt and a dry finish.  Medium body, warmth and carbonation.

Andrewsdad thank you for this want! Nice sour smell with a little nit of pumpkin towards the end. Looks hazy yellow with white head all over the place. Nice sourness all the way throughout. Little bit of a cock tease with the pumpkin. This beer is about 6 months old so would like to try it fresh

Couple of samples at EBF Night of the Barrels. Light orange with an off-white head. Did not get any pumpkin, more brett, oak, apple and light cherry. Tart and sour, medium body and carbonation, becomes nice and dry as you progress, leaves a nice grass and bit of funk taste on the palate. However had this after Daryl and I think it suffered in comparison.
A Sim rate (EBF Night of the Barrels): Sour cherry flavour with a sweet aroma. Very delightful with a sour finish.

Pours a bit murky amber on a thicker body with a light tan head. The aroma is right up my alley, funky Brett at a peak point for aroma with a light sweetness to help complement it. The flavor is the perfect balance of Brett yeast funk and sour with a bit of tart settling on the end

Allagash ghoulschip. 375ml bottle courtesy of Wallace... Cork pops to a mild degree. Pours a hazy orangey brown hue and topped with a creamy white head... Sweet toasty caramel grains, yams with light oak.  
Pumpkin subtle in the background with a light tartness... Flavors are continuation of the same with a light oak tartness to start things off with a softer pumpkin and yam essence albeit very lightly induced overall. Soft pillowy body with a light level of carbonation.  Nicely executed and glad to have tried but somewhat underwhelmed as a whole.
7/4/7/4/15

375ml, bottled in September 2011.  My bottle said 6.9% ABV (not the 8.5% that is listed).  The pour yields a clear, dark, golden apple juice colored body.  Beautiful pinpoint bubbles stream towards the surface, feeding a tall, foamy, off-white head.  Slowly, the foam recedes to a thin center film with a thick, ramped up edge that lasts.  Tall, splotchy, rounded flares of lace cling to the glass.  The nose starts out with notes of tart, musty apples, showing ample acetic sourness and hints of cider vinegar.  Softer lactic, milky, yeasty tartness is also prominent.  Dry brett is less noticeable.  Underlying malts are kind of sweet and appley.  Pumpkin is certainly nowhere to be found.  Flavors largely follow suit, loaded with sweet-tart apple and sweet cereal in the malt base.  Buggy brett is soft and earthen, touching also on some pineapple.  The acetic character is slightly softer than it is on the nose, taking on more of the milky, lactic elements.  Theres nothing overly complex going on here.  Its really just a vinegary, tart, buggy orchard fruit sour.  The palate checks in a bit heftier than medium bodied, due primarily to some saccharine sugars that linger after the crispness of the fine carbonation subsides.  Eh....not a huge fan of this one.  Its OK, but it could be a heck of alot more.  Disappointing coming from Allagash.

Appearance: Pours a dark rust orange with no head.

Aroma. Sour funk, white wine like.

Taste. Not pumpkin like at all. Similar to  a golden sour with pronounced white wine barrel notes.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied with lively bubbles.

Overall: Solid, fun, not pumpkin like at all.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2011 (Drank as Ghoulschip.)  Never would I imagine giving such a high score to a damned pumpkin beer.  But here we are, with Allagash striking the perfect balance between a lovely sour ale and a nutty, sweet pumpkin brew.  Which means, of course, theres a good bit of sour and not much pumpkin.  But there is a toasty, nutlike backbone to the sourness, while the molasses oozes through on the finish, rounding out the oak with a textured, lovely fade.  One of the first beers we opened at this years War on Christmas Beer Party, supplied by Yonke, and it might be top three of the night.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of Satchboogie. A very huge thanks! Moderately cloudy, orange appearance with a small off white head. Musty, cobweb, barnyard, moderate pumpkin, light caramel, lemon citrusy aroma. Spicy pumpkin, caramel malty, tangerine, lemon citrusy, tangy, moderately sour, musty, light oaky flavor. Tangy, tart citrusy, light caramel/pumpkin aftertaste. Very interesting beer.

Thanks a ton Aaron! 375 mL bottle pour is very hazy orange with nice big bubbled white head, aroma has big notes of sour lemon, pumpkin puree, slight white grape, hints of funk and slight caramel, and even more pumpkin, hints of oak in there as well.  Taste is a nice mix of pumpkin, caramel and biscuit, some slight bitter grass and spice, lactic lemony sourness in there with a hint of funk, a slight hint of metallic but not in a bad way, but a very interesting flavor not much like the aroma.
375 ml. Bottle pour.  Poured a hazy orange color.  Barnyard funk sourness.  Get some spices and apple.  Very different and good.  Nice complexity.  Not much pumpkin flavor though.

375mL tossed into the Tilquin tumbler. Ruddy burnt orange, almost opaque. Not much carbonation. Light funk, hay, some vinegar...slightly reminds me of Interludes nose. Tase is out of this world...berry seeds, light notes of currant, some gourd, brett, and a dubbels malt bill. Medium, slick mouthfeel that keeps the beer on the tounge. A bit dry, earthy, and suprisingly mellow. Very interesting wild from Allagash, would love to revisit in a year or so.

Draft. Pours orange with a thin head. Funky and wild aroma, with some light tart cherry and hints at spices. The flavor has funky bretty yeast, a light sweetness, rhubarb, light pumpkin-like spices, and a dry finish. Nice.

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2011 The aroma is sour apples, cherries,  oak. The appearance is  hazy orange,  white  head.  The flavor is sour  fruit, cherry, vinegar, spicy. The finish is  sour cherry, vegetable. Medium in body, maybe a bit watery. Good, not much pumpkin in this beer.   Maybe it needs to warm up a bit. And BTW, I like the name "Drunken Promise" better than "Ghoulschip".

Tap at Churchkey as Allagash Ghoulship. The pour is a hazy deep orange with a thin, yellow film for a head. Dwindles to a flat pour. No lace. Nose is very sharp vinous notes, balsamic, coconut, aceto heat, buttery pumpernickel bread. Taste up front is sour apples, moving to pretty heavy buttery apples. Finish is thin and tart with off flavors of cardboard and metals. Stinging mouthfeel. Much too buttery and no pumpkin flavor whatsoever.

On tap at Churchkey. Cloudy amber pour with a fair sized frothy ivory head. Nose holds excellent notes of pumpkin seed, toasty nut, candied dates, fig, apricot, cheesecloth and cheesecake, and nice tangy funk. Flavor holds good pumpkin, stone fruit, and that beautiful tangy finish. Great woody vanilla as well. This is lovely stuff.

As "Allagash Ghoulschip" at Churchkey. Poured a cloudy dark orange color with a small wispy off-white head. Aroma was spice notes, sour funk. Notes of pumpkin are in there, but are extremely subtle. This was extremely drinkable and quite enjoyable.
On tap at Novare 5/26/11.  Finally found this elusive little beer.  Very mild pumpkin flavor, perhaps through the years its muted out a lot.  Sweet and smooth, with an afterkick of funk.

Reviewed from notes. On cask at Night of the Funk. Pumpkin lambic, I like it already. Pour yields a hazy caramel-brown with a thin off-white head. Nose has a bit of pumpkin there, though Im sure thats a bit of bias knowing that its in there. Nonetheless, good notes of funk and Brett come through to dry this one out and throw in a really rustic character. The flavor does actually have a touch of gourd and earthy hay and funk. Pretty good and nicely unique, though nothing earth-shattering. Feel is a bit prickly given the serving format and has a nice mellow funk. Drinks quite well and certainly points for originality (along with a shout out to Jolly Pumpkin for working a similar concept).

Serving type: cask

Reviewed on: 03-15-2011
(Draught)  Pours a cloudy orange body with a spare white head.  Aroma of pumpkin, herbs, earth, some barnyard, and citrus.  Flavor of tangy citrus, pumpkin, earth, brett, and grass.

Cloudy Orange, Brown pour.  Aroma is spicy, funky, some squash/vegetative elements to the aroma, but not incredibley distinct.  Mouthfeel is medium with a bit of creaminess.  Flavor is funky wood with lots of smooth pumpkin and sharp acidity.  Funky, a little wierd, but I actually liked it.
Orange brown pour with a small white head. Spicy clove and nutmeg give way to sweet pumpkin malt. Brett sourness is prevalent but never overpowering. Medium to full body with a sticky, acidic finish.

Pouring at Night of the Funk on the Friday night of Belgian Beer Fest in Boston.  Pours a hazed golden orange with a thin white head.  Bretty sourness up front, acid and spice.  Pumpkin, balsamic vinegar, acetic acid.  Loads of acid, nice sourness, but too acetic overall.
on tap @Doughertys-pours an off white head and gold color.  Aroma is medium malt.  Taste is medium malt-pumpkin.
Clear amber color/ fleeting head. Big aspirin aroma with some mild pumpkin. medium bodied. Super sour lactic, barf, acidic aspirin flavors with some mild pumpkin. Sour bugs gone wild.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: On tap at the 2009 Great Pumpkin Festival, Cambridge Brewing Company, Cambridge MA on 31 October 2009. This was billed as the worlds first Pumpkin Lambic and was the beer I had been anticipating most at the festival. However, whilst not bad, I found it a little disappointing. No discernible spicing (not sure there is supposed to be any), which was not a problem for me. However, it was neither as sour, nor as funky, as I had hoped. There was a subtle farmyard edge to the aroma and a gentle tartness but it was comprehensively outfunked by the Elysian Mr Yuck I had sampled earlier. Also a rather sweet mouthfeel. Admittedly it was still quite young so perhaps it will develop rather more funky action with time. As it at the moment though I couldnt rank it higher than middle of the road. Extra points for invention though.
Orange-amber, great head. Full sugar pumpkin aroma. Flavors of vanilla, luxurious pumpkin. Crisp aroma and flavor. Said to be unspiced, but I detect coriander. Unexpectedly bitter finish.
Pours a murky amber with a thin ring of bubbles.  Smells dry and funky.  Tastes tarte and breaddy.  Very one dimensional.  Meh.

Oak tartness on the nose. Pretty funky with some wine like notes as well. Pours gold with a thin head. The flavor is buggy and tart. A good deal of funk, and some sour fruit. A touch of alcohol maybe. Interesting and strong up front, the finish is almost non existent. Light tartness perhaps.

Deeply hazy medium copper with plenty of streams of fast-rising bubbles. Thin, moussy, whitish head. Enormous tart strawberry nose. Creamy, softly fizzy medium body. Tart, soft strawberry mid-palate with not much else happening; a little bit of yeasty sweetness there. Mid-palate goes to nothing, leaving a neutral finish. Really a beautiful start that unfortunately doesn’t deliver. Needs more complexity on the back end.

Tap at the Blind Tiger. Fantastic. Bretty, horsey, peanut aroma, with some rich oak and barnyard, with minor pumpkin squash and a touch of spice. Fluffy head, very pale pour; not the typical orange of most pumpkin beers. Flavor is super rich, nutty, with subtle pumpkin and no spice. A touch of wine from the oak. Deeply complex and just awesome to drink. Excellent!

On tap at Bling Tiger.  Pours a super cloudy orange with a thick white head.  Aroma of funk, sour fruits, sweetness, spices.  Flavor is pretty spicy, with Beligan yeast, witbier notes (clove), sweet sourness.  Rather dry.  Not really any pumpkin here but it was a good sour.  Nice brettiness!

Tap @ Blind Tiger. I think I got one of the last ones because it kicked very soon after. Cloudy light golden in color with a nice white head. Fruity yeasty pumpkiny aroma. Orange and lemony bretty notes. Yeasty tart and bretty flavor. Horse blanket, tart and spicy notes. Peppery and clove finish.  Medium bodied.  Very drinkable. Nice beer.

Tap at Blind Tiger. Despite the name, the both the most notable and most impressive character in this beer comes from a nose of a bunch of bretty notes, must, lemon, pineapple, manure, dusty attic. In the mouth some pumpkin does mingle with the brett and woody notes. Very dry. Nice stuff.

Tap at Blind Tiger: Pours a cloudy light golden with a lacing white head. Has a zesty nose- some orange/lemon zest, a touch of earthy tartness, leather and farmhouse notes. The mouth feel is fluffy and lively. Has a crisp flavor with evident brett character. Zesty, with farmhouse notes, musty horse blanket, oak, leathery notes, lemon peel, and a nice yeasty dryness. There’s isn’t much pumpkin, and if I didn’t know this were one, I’d guess it to be a nice brett-y Belgian style ale. Has a peppery finish with maybe a clove note? and residual leathery/mild oak earthiness. Not a necessarily a "pumpkin beer", but a great beer overall.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2008 Draught @ Blind Tiger. Pours a cloudy, orange-tinted gold with a pillowy white head. Aroma is earthy, slightly musty yeast, ripe golden fruit, slightly vegetal with the pumpkin peeking through just a bit. Flavor begins with a very crisp wheat character thats infused with a yeasty/funky aspect thats almost salty, a bit dry. Pumpkin starts to emerge towards the finish, nutmeg/cinnamon are very restrained for the style - pumpkin aspect is quite vegetal, clear, prominent towards the finish, melding with the yeasty, earthy spice on the finish. Medium carbonation, slightly soft, medium body. One of my favorite pumpkin brews, but I would love to get this in bottles in order to set some back for a while.

Woo-hoo, rating #1.  On tap at Blind Tiger.  Very hazy yellow-golden brew topped by a thick creamy white head.  Aroma is very musty and minerally with nice bretty perfumey notes.  Lots of crisp wheaty spiciness along with a touch of pumpkiny spice over that.  Very interesting brew.  Warming brings up a bit more pumpkiny aroma over that bretty/boney/minerally nose that invites me to drink even more of it.  Mmmm, wow, this is great.  The flavour is quite sticky/chewy initially but beyond that, there is a lot of pumpkin flavour.  Sort of wheaty with the pumpkin playing a dominent role.  Light cinnamon/clove but none of the typical allspice that seems to define this style.  The aroma is more intense than the flavour, which comes across quite sweet and a little bit starchy.  Also some lightly honeyish flavour, but with loads of bretty flavour as well and a bit of lingering citrus.  I really hope they bottle this, because the brett is only starting to dry this out... another four to five months and this will really come into it’s own.  A very unusual take on the style.  It’s like they did a cereal mash with loads of pumpkin, fermented it, then spiked it with brett.  Man, I love these guys... another solid brew.
